TopicTitle: Can I install KSP directly onto a thumb drive?

Articles.Content:
Hi guys!

With 1.2 out, I am updating my game, but I would like to put it onto a thumb drive, so I can play it on any PC. Can I just tell it to unzip onto the thumb drive, or do I have to install it on a PC, then move it over onto the thumb drive?

 

Thanks!

Yes, you can put it on a thumbdrive, and run it from there. I could only make blind guesses at performance - game startup speed will likely be negatively affected unless it's a high quality stick - but there is nothing about the game that prevents it from a technical standpoint. It doesn't install registry keys, it doesn't write to the user profile or partially resides in %appdata%, and it doesn't generate relevant amounts of data volume while playing.

You can even save on file size quite a bit by deleting the data folder for the game version you know you are not going to play. For instance, if you know you'll only ever start 64bit mode, just toss KSP_Data. If you know you'll only ever run 32bit, then removing KSP_x64_Data keeps the install footprint small.

Edited October 23, 2016 by nascarlaser1

When you say "it defaulted", then I presume you bought the game via Steam, and started it via Steam until now. (I personally don't know how the Squad launcher works...)

But if you put it on a thumbdrive, you can't start it that way. Instead, you'll have to run the executable directly. KSP nowadays comes with two: KSP.exe, and KSP_x64.exe. You can probably guess which does what.

The difference between 32bit and 64bit is, as far as stock KSP is concerned, close to zero. The big differences show up when you get into modding. In 64bit mode, KSP can address more RAM while it is running. The stock game never runs out of RAM on its own, but by adding mods, you can push it past the threshold up to which 32bit works. If that happens, the game crashes instantly. Unless, of course, you were running 64bit, because in that case, RAM limitations don't exist (provided you physically have enough in the computer). The downside of 64bit mode is that it requires you to have a 64bit operating system, as well as a 64bit CPU underneath. But mind you: that kind of hardware has existed for so long, any computer that is physically capable of running KSP will automatically have it. 64bit Windows operating systems have existed since the Windows XP days (Linux/Unix for much longer). But it was uncommon for consumers in those days to use it, because it wasn't the most stable or compatible. By the time Windows 7 rolled around, it was fully stable and the majority of users went for it. Not sure if something newer than Windows 7 even exists in 32bit form.

And as far as KSP is concerned? Historically, 32bit was standard. 64bit never ran well, because Unity was buggy. When KSP ported to a new Unity version in 1.1, this problem disappeared, and now pretty much everyone is using 64bit all the time. As long as your computer supports it, there is zero downside, and when using mods, all the upside.
... except for the very odd fact that an unmodded KSP 32bit seems to load and run a fair bit faster than the 64b version on my system.
